_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Family Tree Farms - Executive Summary



    Family Tree Farms operates a fruit packing facility at 41646 Road 62, near Dinuba, Tulare County, CA. The facility is

used to receive, clean, grade, pack and store seasonal stone fruit. The packing season runs from May through October. The 

number of employees varies widely depending on the season, from 15 year-round personnel to 360 at peak packing season. Packed

fruit is stored at the facility in cold storage until shipped. The refrigeration system for the cold storage uses anhydrous

ammonia as a refrigerant, and so 3,800 gallons of this material is kept on site. Additionally, the facility heating systems

use propane, so up to 1,000 gallons of this fuel is also kept on site.



    The ammonia is in a closed system, with minimal handling of the material required. The most serious risk of a spill

comes from the accidential rupture of the system storage container or piping, or a spill during unusual maintenance of the

system. Ammonia refrigeration systems are widely used, and design features are included to minimize the risk of accidental

release. This facility is modern and incorporates current safety design. However, Family Tree Farms has a policy that 

prevention is by far the best method of avoiding accidental releases of ammonia. Therefore, regular scheduled inspection and 

maintenance is carried out to assure the system is in good condition. The company follows IIAR safety and maintenance 

recommendations outlined in "Minimum Safety Criteria For A Safe Ammonia Refrigeration System" (Bulletin # 109 of the 

International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration). Maintenance personnel are given special training prior to unusual 

maintenance operations to reduce the risk of accidental releases during maintenance.



    An Emergency Action Plan is in place to react to accidental ammonia releases. The plan includes notification and 

evacuation plans for all employees, notification of emergency responders, and notificati

on of neighbors. The plan is 

coordinated with Tulare County Fire Department. This agency also makes annual inspections of the facility which among other 

things allows the reponders to become familiar with the facility layout and equipment.



    All employees receive training when first hired that includes a briefing on the ammonia refrigeration system and the

hazards of ammonia. Full time employees receive periodic training on the emergency action plan and their duties and 

responsibilities in the event of an accidental release. All seasonal employees are given training at the start of every 

packing season on the evacuation plan and what to do in the event of an emergency. Plant maintenance employees receive train-

ing in first aid for persons affected by ammonia, and in the use of breathing apparatus.



    Planning for leakage of propane follows the plan for an ammonia release.



    Family Tree Farms has had no emergencies related to hazardous or flammable materials in the last five years.
